position.marginalia_text: Maharbalis absolutum consilium, Annibalem reddere potuisset magnum: vt erat Alexander magnus. Sed minoribus commodis intentus Annibal, maximarum rerum amittit occasionem vnicam. Vel nunc, vel nunq[uam]. Maharbalis, tanq[uam] Achitophelis peremptorium consilium, instar oraculi. Pra[e]potentis victoris fuisset pra[e]senti animo, et acerrima alacritate correptum, statim volitasse Romam: et Vrbem alioqui invictam
, ex improuiso capere attonitam, ac terrore confusam. Certè Alexander, et Ca[e]sar iam iamq[ue] fecissent fulmineo impetu.

marginalia.translation: Maharbal’s bold advice could have made Hannibal great like Alexander was great. Yet as he was focused on smaller benefits, he missed a unique opportunity for really great achievements. It was now or never. Maharbal’s advice, just as the decisive one of Achitophel’s, was equal to an oracle. It would have been typical of a superior winner to be won over by his ready mind and really keen eagerness, and hurry immediately to Rome and to take by surprise an otherwise unconquered city, stunned and confused by panic. Alexander first and then Caesar certainly achieved this with an attack with the speed of lightning.

position.marginalia_text: = Occasio in puncto. Aut nunc: aut nunq[uam].

marginalia.translation: Opportunity lies in an instant. It is either now or never.

position.marginalia_text: Unicè expedit ingenti viro, magnarum occasionum momenta instantissimè arripere stupendo vigore: et cum interest pra[e]potentem Ducem agere, Hoc agere tremenda vi: nec inausum vllo modo relinquere, quod conducat maximè. Accessorium sequitur principale: et vnum magnum instar mille modicorum. Tunc deficit Annibal, cum in primis oportuisset excedere: maximè in capienda Roma, et defendenda Carthagine. Vbi audebat Animo vincere, vincebat corpore: vbi vacillabat virtus, ruebat Fortuna. Magna[e] cura[e] magna merces: et contrà.

marginalia.translation: It is particularly expedient for a great man most insistently to grasp important opportunities with stunning vigor, and, when it is expedient for a powerful leader to act, to do this with tremendous force, and not to leave untried anything whatsoever that may be especially helpful. The accessory follows the principal part and one great result is equal to a thousand mediocre ones. Hannibal faltered at the moment when he should, above all, have proceeded, especially with capturing Rome and defending Carthage. When he mentally dared to win, he won with physically, when valour wavered, Fortune collapsed. The great price of great worries, and the other way around.
